unnormalised: Okay, so you're serious about your sport, right? Whether you're aiming for the Ranji Trophy or just crushing your local badminton tournament in Chembur, a solid training regimen is non-negotiable. Think of it as the secret masala in your athlete's biryani. It's what separates good from legendary.
normalised: Okay, so you are serious about your sport, right? Whether you are aiming for the Ranji Trophy or just crushing your local badminton tournament in Chembur, a solid training regimen is non-negotiable. Think of it as the secret masala in your athlete's biryani. It is what separates good from legendary.

unnormalised: First things first, forget those half-hearted gym sessions after college. We're talking about a structured, personalized plan. Consult with a good coach, maybe someone from the NIS Patiala if you can swing it. They can assess your fitness level, identify your weaknesses (that weak left hook, or stamina that dips after the 70th over) and tailor a program accordingly.

Consult with a good coach, maybe someone from the N I S Patiala if you can swing it. They can assess your fitness level, identify your weaknesses (that weak left hook, or stamina that dips after the seventieth over) and tailor a program accordingly.

unnormalised: Now, what should this regimen look like? It's gotta be holistic. Strength training is key, even for seemingly "non-strength" sports like Kabaddi. Think squats, deadlifts, bench presses, all that jazz. Get those muscles firing! And don't forget core work! A strong core is the foundation for everything, from a powerful serve in tennis to a stable batting stance in cricket. Imagine Virat Kohli with a wobbly core – wouldn't be pretty, would it?

unnormalised: Cardio is equally important. Long runs, interval training, cycling – mix it up! Maybe a scenic 5 km jog along Marine Drive followed by some killer hill sprints in Lonavala? Keeps things interesting and challenges your body in different ways.
normalised: Cardio is equally important. Long runs, interval training, cycling – mix it up! Maybe a scenic five kilometer jog along Marine Drive followed by some killer hill sprints in Lonavala? Keeps things interesting and challenges your body in different ways.

unnormalised: And nutrition! You can't fuel a Ferrari with Rs. 50 petrol, can you? You need the premium stuff. Talk to a sports nutritionist. They'll tell you about the right balance of carbs, protein, and fats for your specific sport and training schedule. Think dal roti, chicken tikka (in moderation!), and plenty of fruits and vegetables. No skipping the lassi after a tough workout!

unnormalised: Rest and recovery are just as crucial as the training itself. Muscles grow and repair during rest. Aim for at least 7-8 hours of sleep per night. Consider incorporating active recovery days – a light swim, yoga, or even just a leisurely walk in Lodhi Garden. Foam rolling is your friend!

unnormalised: Track your progress! Keep a training journal, noting your weights lifted, distances covered, and how you're feeling. This helps you identify patterns, adjust your training load, and avoid overtraining. Many athletes are now using wearable tech, too, tracking everything from heart rate to sleep patterns.

unnormalised: Finally, remember that consistency is key. A sporadic burst of intense training followed by weeks of inactivity is worse than steady, consistent effort. Think of it like building a house. You can't just throw bricks on a patch of land of 100 sq ft. You need a solid foundation and consistent work to create a lasting structure. And don't be afraid to adjust your training plan as you go. As they say in cricket, adapt to the conditions!
